item.title: Comment on The New Zealand sheep-to-people ratio continues to fall by Nicholas Kerr
item.description:
Surprisingly big miss that the authors of this blog post don't provide the real economic reason behind the beginning of this steep decline. They primarily call out the decline in the price of wool. But the reason that anyone familiar with the New Zealand story is that it all began with the removal of government subsidies for farming in 1984. Prior to that time, nearly 40 percent of the average New Zealand sheep and beef farmer’s gross income came from government subsidies and price support. With that removal, as CATO had noted: "New Zealand farmers cut costs, diversified their land use, sought nonfarm income, and developed new products. Farmers became more focused on pursuing activities that made good business sense."

item.title: Comment on The New Zealand sheep-to-people ratio continues to fall by Nicholas Kerr
item.description:
Reply to Hadur:

When Australia and New Zealand leave the sheep game because they are worried about animal rights and carbon emissions, some other country or countries will step up and produce more sheep to fill the resulting gap in demand. Whoever that other country is, it will almost certainly have laxer animal rights laws and laxer environmental laws. So all Australia and NZ will have accomplished is worsening animal rights and increasing carbon emissions.

Now, "Great Reset" conspiracy theorists likely think that AUS/NZ leaders understand all this and this is all just part of some plot to emiserate the west and turn us all into serfs or whatever. But a far more likely - and far more terrifying - possibility is the fact that these politicians do not actually have rational goals and are just chasing good feelings.

If a politician has rational goals, you can at least bargain with them, even if they are corrupt or evil. They can be reasoned with. A politician who is chasing feelings? Not so.

I get your point if this was what caused the decline in the New Zealand sheep populations. But as I noted in my other comment, this is actually a story of politicians doing the right thing and getting out of the way of farmers. In 1984, they removed price controls and subsidies and let the market work. Farmers found more profitable activities and many moved away from sheep farming as a result.

item.title: Comment on Thursday assorted links by luzh
item.description:
Reply to Bob:

5. Your average person on the street knows nothing about economics, and therefore ends up thinking that rent control makes it easier to afford rent. They couldn't put themselves in the POV of a landlord for 5 seconds if they tried. The same happens when people in the suburbs pick policies that are supposed to increase value and lower car congestion, as they haven't studied the actual dynamics of it all.

It'd be nice to have an electorate that understood that the policies they want do the opposite of their policy goals, but that's what we've got.

Economics is the study of a complex system, like the weather, or an organism. Modeling a complex system in an interpretable way is extremely difficult, maybe impossible, but yet at least when it comes to weather, climate, and medicine most voters agree that meteorology and evidence-based medical science are the most appropriate ways to approach the problem -- highly imperfect, but the best option we have.

This is not the case with economics. It seems like most voters don't trust economists, or economics, at all. Is that unavoidable, because economics is inherently more predictable, or is it something that economics as a profession bears some blame for?

#3: Related, one thing I saw that surprised me when looking at datasets was that the proportion of "High Tech Goods" Exports, "ICT Goods" Exports and "ICT Services" have on average equalised a bit in absolute terms between the EU and the US, compared to either the immediately pre-GFC point of 2007, or the early 2000s. Or else they've stayed constant.

Unusual versus most dialogue where you might thinking of it as a gap which widens over time since 2000. Maybe we forget how much more concentrated things were in the 1990s and 2000s, in technology sectors, compared to a more globalized era in the 2010s? We don't look so much at the longer trend. I guess the tricky bit is that you can't tell if these are simply exports-imports between European states which would be counted as internal trade within the US, and don't really signify much in "global competitiveness", outside the union, so it's apples to oranges.

item.description:
6. GPT-4 context: Tyler Cowen's comment, "Lord Monboddo vindicated," refers to the 18th-century Scottish judge and philosopher James Burnett, Lord Monboddo. Monboddo is known for his controversial ideas about the origins of language and human evolution. One of his theories was that human language developed from animal communication, and he speculated that apes, particularly orangutans, might have the ability to use sophisticated language or at least a complex form of communication.

Monboddo made his assertions about the origins of language and the possible connection between human and ape communication in his work "Of the Origin and Progress of Language." This six-volume series was published between 1773 and 1792.
